For release PMs Wednesday, Dec. 27
Upcoming: The Big Experiment With Market Economies
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps no decade this century has begun amid greater economic unpheaval, challenge and potential than the 1990s, and it isn't due solely to the fall of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Western Europe too is in the midst of historic changes scheduled to begin in little more than a year with integration of the European Economic Community. Japan is facing adjustments because of competition. The American challenge is as big as any of them. It must solidify the great accomplishments of the 1980s, bring down inflation, steer the way through an economic downturn, reduce the trade deficit and balance budgets. Japan, which ascended to economic dominance in many trade areas during the 1980s, is faced with demands to make its economy more receptive to imports, to reduce its trade surplus and perhaps to develop its infrastructure. China is trying to lift itself to world economic standards in the production of goods. Hong Kong faces a change of sponsorship from Britain to China. Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and other small Asian nations face the challenge of remaining competitive while lifting living standards. Confronted with evidence of superior lifestyles in more highly developed countries, much of Africa, Latin America and the Mideast are in political and economic ferment that no longer can be repressed. Amid the confusion, there are few blueprints for the future so carefully defined as that of the European Economic Community. There is no clear procedure for turning centrally planned economies into market economies. Nor is there time to develop plans. Instant communication produces instant change, but contributes little toward identifying programs for carrying out the changes. The demands for change are swift, the implementation remains slow. Through all of the changes, however, there is at least one constant factor, opportunity. For major trading nations it means new markets. For underdeveloped nations it means the chance to radically lift depressed living standards. For all nations it means a more productive allocation of resources and skills. Managed well, the changes could be a great leap forward for the world community. Prospects for Western Europe, for example, already had brightened with the scheduled removal of trade barriers among 12 nations in 1992. Now, says Albert Cox Jr., economic analyst with the investment counseling firm Bil, Trainer Wortham Inc., ``there is the possibility of massive growth in international trade in the next 10 years.'' If that happens, he concludes, ``history tells us that greatly enhanced world economic prosperity will be the end result.'' No matter what economic changes occur throughout the world, they are bound to have an impact on domestic politics and economic direction within the United States. Already Washington is debating the possibilities of the so-called peace dividend, or billions of dollars in funds that supposedly will be available as a result of a cutback in defense programs. But that is only the beginning. If the world's experimentation with market economies continues, it will provide a showcase for those seeking to direct the American economy toward the most efficient ends. Conceivably, it could even mean an approach to that long-sought American goal of shrinking the federal government while maintaining and even improving services to the public.
